Key Findings

  • The ENVIRONMENT AND PLACE department received £17.9M, accounting for 12.5% of the total spend.
  • Environmental Services spent £17.3M, which is 12.1% of the total spend.
  • The RESOURCES department spent £16.0M, making up 11.2% of the total spend, while the Resources department spent £11.6M, accounting for 8.1% of the total spend.
  • Health & Housing spent £11.3M, which is 7.9% of the total spend.
  • The total spend analysed is £143.2M across the 4 financial years from 2021/22 to 2025/26.

Departmental Spending Breakdown

The spending data for Lancaster City Council reveals that the top departments in terms of expenditure are ENVIRONMENT AND PLACE, Environmental Services, and RESOURCES. The ENVIRONMENT AND PLACE department received £17.9M, which is the highest amount among all departments. This is followed by Environmental Services, which spent £17.3M.

The RESOURCES department spent £16.0M, while the Resources department spent £11.6M. Health & Housing spent £11.3M, which is 7.9% of the total spend. These figures indicate that the council's environment and resource-related departments are among the largest recipients of funds.

A closer look at the spending data reveals that the top 5 departments account for over 50% of the total spend. The £17.9M spent by ENVIRONMENT AND PLACE, £17.3M spent by Environmental Services, £16.0M spent by RESOURCES, £11.6M spent by Resources, and £11.3M spent by Health & Housing add up to £74.1M, which is 51.7% of the total spend.

What You Can Do

  • Submit a Freedom of Information request to Lancaster City Council about the specific projects and initiatives that the ENVIRONMENT AND PLACE department is funding with its £17.9M budget.
  • Attend council committee meetings, which are open to the public, to learn more about the council's spending decisions and to ask questions about the allocation of funds.
  • Check the council's published contracts register to see which suppliers are being used for different services and to find out more about the council's procurement processes.
  • Write to your local councillor about your concerns regarding the council's spending priorities and to ask for more information about the initiatives and projects that are being funded.
  • Visit aidoge.co.uk to explore the full spending data and to gain a better understanding of how the council's funds are being used.
This article is based on Lancaster City Council's published spending data covering 2021/22 to 2025/26. All figures are drawn directly from transactions published under the Local Government Transparency Code. Analysis by AI DOGE.
